comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content: I would need to see a higher resolution photograph to confirm my suspicion, but I think that this is the construction of the Captain Cook Graving Dock at Garden Island. The perspective of the photograph appears to have been taken from a high point on the island or a crane looking back towards Woolloomoolloo. If my suspicion is correct, then this photograph has been taken between 1940 and early 1945. Probably closer to the earlier part of that tiem span. See some photographs taken mainly in the opposite perspective here: www.gardenisland.info/1-02-010.html The construction of the Captain Cook Graving Dock was a great engineering feat, and assisted the war effort after opening.

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content:
Yes, it's the construction of the Captain Cook Graving Dock at Garden Island.

It's early in the construction, before the coffer dam has been put in place at the mouth of the dock and the water pumped out to permit further excavation.

I'm working on a more precise date.

comment.author: 61804295@N00
comment._content: I'd love to see a shot a little further around to the right. My Grandfather had a house there, "Wyldefel", the front yard extended down to the Harbour. He had this development constructed upon it before the war. www.flickr.com/photos/spelio/3666393845/ Then the Navy resumed the bottom section, and moved one of the units over to Kurraba Point... www.flickr.com/photos/spelio/3177092046/

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/spelio] Spelio, one of the units which were moved over to Kurraba point are up for sale. See here: smh.domain.com.au/real-estate-news/once-upon-a-time-there... The triplex stands at 115A Kurraba Road, Neutral Bay.

comment.author: 63385174@N06
comment._content: This photograph is most definitely REVERSED. In the photo, Woolloomooloo finger wharf is on the left (should be on the right). You can see the number "7" reversed on the Woolloomooloo wharf at high res. I wondered why I couldn't orientate the picture.
